content: The Act may be cited as the "One Strike You're Out, Part II Act" and includes screening of prospective assisted families. The "One Strike You're Out, Part II Act" amends the United States Housing Act of 1937 to allow public housing agencies to deny assistance to criminal offenders in the same way owners of federally assisted housing can deny occupancy. This includes screening of prospective assisted families. The "One Strike You're Out, Part II Act" allows public housing agencies to limit assistance to criminal offenders, similar to how owners of federally assisted housing can deny occupancy. The "One Strike You're Out, Part II Act" allows public housing agencies to limit assistance to criminal offenders through occupancy screening. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 allows owners of federally assisted housing to deny occupancy to applicants or household members engaged in criminal activities within the past 3 years. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 allows owners of federally assisted housing to deny occupancy to applicants or household members engaged in criminal activities within the past 3 years. Owners may also require access to criminal records of adult household members as a condition of providing occupancy. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 allows owners of federally assisted housing to access criminal records of adult household members as a condition of providing occupancy. SEC. 4. TERMINATION OF TENANCY. Public Housing - Amended procedures for expedited grievance and leases under the United States Housing Act of 1937. Grievances involving eviction or termination of tenancy must meet specific criteria. Tenancy termination only allowed for lease violations, breaking laws, or good cause. The amended procedures for expedited grievance and leases under the United States Housing Act of 1937 allow for termination of tenancy if any activity threatens the health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment of the premises by other tenants or residents in the vicinity, or if it involves criminal activity. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for termination of tenancy if there is a violation of the lease terms, applicable laws, or other good cause, including activities that threaten the health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment of other tenants or employees. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for termination of tenancy for violations that threaten the health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment of others, including criminal activity on or off the premises. The United States Housing Act of 1937 allows for termination of tenancy for violations that threaten health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment, including criminal activity on or off the premises. SEC. 645 specifies the process for termination of tenancy. The lease for federally assisted housing states that the owner can only terminate tenancy for lease violations, violation of laws, or good cause. Any activity that threatens the health, safety, or peaceful enjoyment of other tenants or employees can lead to termination. The lease for federally assisted housing allows termination of tenancy for lease violations, violation of laws, or good cause. Any activity that threatens the peaceful enjoyment of other residents or involves drug-related criminal activity can result in termination. Drug-related criminal activity includes illegal manufacture, sale, distribution, or possession of controlled substances. SEC. 6. AVAILABILITY OF CRIMINAL RECORDS FOR TENANT SCREENING AND EVICTION. Subtitle C of title VI of the Housing and Community Development Act of 1992 is amended to add a new section regarding the availability of criminal records for tenant screening and eviction. The National Crime Information Center and law enforcement agencies must provide criminal conviction records of adult applicants or tenants in federally assisted housing upon request from the owner for screening, lease enforcement, and eviction purposes, with written authorization from the applicant. The paragraph provides guidelines for the release of criminal conviction information of juvenile applicants in federally assisted housing, subject to state laws. Before taking adverse action based on a criminal record, the tenant must be given a chance to dispute its accuracy. A reasonable fee may be charged for providing this information, and proper records management is required for all agencies and owners receiving such information. Federally assisted housing must maintain confidentiality, prevent misuse, and destroy criminal records once the purpose is fulfilled. The term 'adult' refers to individuals 18 years or older or those convicted as adults under federal, state, or tribal law.
